Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Supraclavicular and Retroclavicular Brachial Plexus Block on Diaphragmatic Function

Trial_Design.evidence: This double-blinded, randomised controlled trial was conducted at a single tertiary hospital from December 2017 to May 2019.

Participants.evidence: Forty patients undergoing upper extremity surgery below the axilla were randomised to receive either SCB or RCB with ropivacaine 0.5%. Exclusion criteria included significant pulmonary disease, BMI >40, and contraindications to peripheral nerve block.

Intervention.evidence: Forty patients undergoing upper extremity surgery below the axilla were randomised to receive either SCB or RCB with ropivacaine 0.5%.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of phrenic block, assessed by changes in diaphragmatic excursion and maximum inspiratory volume at baseline, 15, 30 minutes postblock, and postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Forty patients were randomised, 20 to each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Forty patients were randomised, 20 to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of phrenic block was significantly higher in the SCB group (70% by ultrasound, 55% by spirometry) compared to the RCB group (15% by ultrasound, 5% by spirometry).
